titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I had this day too, altogether without interruption from visitors— Took an Evening walk in the Summer-Gardens— Mr: Smith and Mr: Gray dined in the Country— I made an Index for one of my blank books, on the model of Locke; and made some further calculations of comparison, for the weights and measures as cited by Maudru & Webster. Read a Charity Sermon of Massillon—in the volume of Mysteres— It is upon the Spirit in which deeds of Charity should be done— An excellent discourse— 1. They should be considered as duties— 2. As remedies for own infirmities. 3. And be free from every selfish motive— This is the disinterested benevolence of the Hopkinsians— But is it human Nature?

2. Visit from Mr: Harris, who mentioned the arrival of a vessel to his address from Baltimore in 56 days— I had some conversation with him respecting the new additional charges of the Commission Merchants, which he approves— Mr: Six paid me a visit also with his Secretary who has just arrived— I called at Etter’s shop; and looked at his books, his gems, Siberian stones, pictures &c— I saw there a Jew, who writes an elegant hand, and gives lessons of Hebrew— Etter shewed me his Russian nest of two pound weights—which had a weight as low as 1/16 of a Solotnik— He also shew me an English pair of Scales for weighing diamonds; with weights of 32. 16. 8. 4. 2 and 1. Carats and of 1/2, 1/4— 1/8 and 1/16 of a Carat. I saw there also a French Dictionary of Arts et Métiers in 5. Volumes, and a French Bible of Osterwald, which I was inclined to purchase, but of which I thought his prices too high— Mr: Smith dined abroad—in the Country— I walked in the Evening, and was caught in a shower.

3. I went over to the Wasily-Ostroff, to look at some furniture to be sold at Auction, and then in a boat with Waldstein, to the fortress, to see if I could procure an authentic set of weights, or get those that I have rectified— The imperial mint is at the island, within the fortress, and I had been informed that the standard weights of the Country were there, and that all others might be officially rectified by them— But on arriving there, I found that the person said to be appointed for this office, was not there; and was invited to return to-morrow.— I went into the Church of the fortress, where I saw the tombs of all the Sovereigns of Russia, since Peter the great—excepting Peter the second and Ivan— On returning home I found a file of Baltimore newspapers to the second of May— In the Evening we had successively visits from Count Luxbourg, and from Mr: Harris, with Mr: Roberts, who is just arrived in the vessel from Baltimore.

4. I had a visit this morning from Mr: Montréal— I went again to the fortress, and saw the director of the Mint—who told me that there were no weights to be sold there, but directed me to a Mr: Hynam, an Englishman, as a person who might give me the information that I wanted— He also ordered that the works at the mint should be shewn me, by an Englishman, under whose direction they are— There are two Steam engines; one of the power of 50 horses and the other of twenty-five, by the means of which the works are principally performed— The silver comes from the Russian Mines— The smelting process, is usually done in the Night and early in the morning— It had ceased for this day, so that I could not see it— From those furnaces the silver is received in short, narrow bars, which by passing between rolling mills, is expanded to a length of about eight feet, and a width and thickness, adequate for the various pieces of coin to be cut from it— From these bars are cut out the blanks which are to serve, as coins, which are first annealed in a hot oven, then pass’d between two cheeks, which round the edge and stamp the impression upon it, and finally coined, by a machine which strikes off from sixty to seventy in a minute— The weight of the rouble is 4. Zolotniks and 82/96—a range of 4/96 of a Zolotnik in excess or in deffciency is allowed for each piece— If the blank is found heavier than this it is filed down to the weight—if lighter it must be melted over again— The remnants of the long bars out of which the blanks are cut must be melted over again— It appears to me that several of the processes would be susceptible of much improvement. There is so much waste of filings and other small particles which get scattered on the floors, that there are brushes at all the doors at which on going out every person must scrape the soles of his boots or shoes to take off the adhering particles; and the mint-man assured me that the amount annually collected from this operation was very considerable— There is little or no gold now coined, and few silver pieces other than roubles— Nor, if I judge of the average, from this days appearance, many of them— One coining machine only was at work, and that tended by a boy.— There are separate rooms for striking medals, where the coining machine is worked by the hand, and not by the steam engine— They were at work upon a medal for the City of Riga, to commemorate the centurial day since its subjection to the Russian Empire— Its date is 4. July 1710 and 1810. On one side are the profile’s of Peter the great, and the present Emperor, facing each other— On the
John 7. years old— Charles 2. f. 11. i.

reverse a view of the City of Riga— The heads are extremely well executed— Particularly that of Peter— The medalist is a German named Leberecht— I enquired if any of them could be procured, when they should be finished; and my companion promised to procure one for me— On my return I sent Waldstein to make enquiries of Mr: Hynam; but he found that he works only for the Emperor— In the Evening I went with the Ladies to the Play and saw Moliere’s Tartuffe, with the ballet of Paul and Virginia— The Comedy was badly performed— Duport danced very well in the ballet.

5. Visit from Mr: Harris, with news, not very important from England. I paid a visit to Mr: Six, and to his Secretary, Mr Van Zuylen van Nyvelt—the latter was not at home— I had much conversation with Mr: Six, who read me an extract from one of his dispatches to his Government, written in consequence of former conversations with me, and urging the expediency of a change in the policy of France, towards the United States— This extract he assures me has been sent to France; and the French Ambassador here has written to his government in the same Spirit— But he appears anxious again respecting the fate of his own Country, and made enquiries relative to the expence of living in America, where he intends with his brother’s family to go in case of necessity.— I afterwards called at Mr: Raimbert’s; but he was not at home. I saw however Mr: Montréal—while I was there a Mr: and Madame Le Brun came in— I walked home, and walked again in the Evening— Met General Pardo on the Quay opposite his own house— He is going in two or three days for Moscow— He begins again to entertain hopes, that the French will eventually be expelled from Spain.

6. Mr: Montréal called upon me this morning with the bills for a draft upon Holland, and I signed the bills— I also wrote on the subject to Messrs: Willink and Van Staphorst.— In the Evening after the exchange, Mr: Montréal sent me a note of the charges of exchange; which amount not quite to one half the charges of Messrs: Meyer & Brüxner. I went to the shops to examine some articles of Furniture, but found them all shut, it being according to the Russian Calendar, the Holiday Festival of St: John the Baptist— On returning from my walk I observed the setting of the Sun, and noticed that its Southern declination was already very considerable— From the 18th: to the 25th: of June it was imperceptible— Mr: Montréal told me this morning that there had been great debates in the Imperial Council, and that Prince Adam Czartoryski, and Count Kotschubey had asked and received permission to go to their Estates.

7. I went this morning to the shops, and made purchases of various articles of furniture, stationary and plate— Together with a brass two pound nest of weights; for the purpose of making further experiments to ascertain the precise amount of the Russian pound— There is no legal standard by which the other weights in this Country are compared. But the shopkeepers who use weights, have them compared and stamped at the Town-House, under the inspection of a police Officer. There is a stamp on the external weight, which contains all the others, but the smaller weights are not stamped; and of course are inaccurate in their proportions— This business engaged me all the morning.— In the Evening I walked on the quay, as far as the Summer-Gardens—

8. I passed the day at home, untill the Evening when I took a long walk, and observed the setting Sun—its Southern declination is very perceptible from day to day— I involved myself deeper in the labyrinth of enquiries concerning weights & measures, and the further I proceed, increase uncertainties and different reports from different authorities. Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray dined abroad; at Mr: Glukoff’s; but were here in the Evening.

9. I received this morning a letter from my Mother of 20. March and one from Mr: William Gray of 21. April; with a bundle of Newspapers from the Editors of the New-England Palladium.— As usual the reading of these papers engrossed my immediate attention, and employed the whole leisure of the morning, untill the hour of dinner came. Mr: Harris called upon me, with some news from Sicily through Copenhagen; of a descant by the French king of Naples, and of the British troops in the island being disarmed— But he did not appear informed of the situation of Prince Czartoryski, and Count Kotschubey.— I dined with Mr: Smith at Mr: Raimbert’s— Mr: Fisher, and Mr: Venning were there, and also Mr: Harris— In the Evening I went with Mr: Harris, to M. de Laval’s in the Country. We there saw Monsr: and Madame de Laval; with their Son and two daughters— General Sabloukoff, and his Lady, and Count Schenk. M. de Laval took me over his gardens, which are very beautiful, and entirely of his own creation— Madame de Laval shewed me a small picture of van der Velde, about which she was very anxious, as one of her friends has told her it was good for nothing; while she herself very much admired it— I was of her opinion, but noticed to her that it had received some damage, which was true.

10. Mr: Gray received letters from his father and family yesterday, and with them a bundle of newspapers which engaged my time almost the whole of this morning— The arrangements and changes of furniture however, occasioned some interruptions. I dined with Mr: Gray at Mr: Six’s; with a company of about twelve, his usual number. He told me that his Salary the first year he came here was fifty thousand florins current a year— And after the first year forty thousand— The whole of which he says he spends— The last St: Petersburg Gazette contains the appointment of Count Stackelberg as Russian Minister at Vienna; with a Salary of twenty thousand Rubles a year, the Ruble to be reckoned at fifty stuivers of Holland—together with five thousand Rubles for expences of outfit and travelling, and 800 Rubles a year for postage— Mr: Six gave me some further information from Holland; and he appears now again to encourage hopes that they will not be totally swallowed up— In the Evening I called to visit Messrs: Roberts, Coffin, Field, and Plummer at Rea’s Hotel, but neither of them was at his lodgings— I then took a long walk upon the Quay of the Neva; and in the Summer Gardens.

11. I enter this day upon the forty-fourth year of my age.— How large a portion of the longest life, I have already past, and to how little purpose. The last year of my life has been one of the most useless in respect to the pursuits which my imagination is so ready to frame before-hand— Let me hope that if another anniversary of my birth-day, is indulged me, I shall be able to give myself a better account of the time— I had this morning a visit from Count John Potocki, who seems to be dissatisfied with the situation of things. His brother, Count Severin, told Mr: Harris that he should very shortly ask the Emperor’s permission to retire from his service— They are not inclined to French politics.— I went to see Mr: Hynam, in pursuit of information respecting the weights and measures of this Country. He is a very ingenious artist, and has reduced the measures to the greatest possible precision. He says the Russian Arsheen is exactly 28 English inches— He has made by order of the Emperor standard metallic measures, for all the Governments of the Empire, from which the Arsheen is to be made, and he has orders himself to make forty-thousand iron-Arsheen rods for the Government— He has an instrument by which he marks the gradation of a 36000th: part of an Inch— But to make it he was obliged to use wood (mahogany) across the grain, and agat stone—for he found that the warmth of the hand produced an expansion of metallic instruments, which was incompatible with this minuteness of accuracy— With regard to weights he had scales to indicate and weights to mark the 400th: part of a grain Troy weight— But though he has obtained orders to have the standard weights at the fortress delivered to him to compare them with the English avoirdupoise and Troy weights which he has, authenticated from the British exchequer, he has not yet obtained them— He has however compared the Standard Zolotnik at the fortress with his own weights, and found it weigh 65 1/2 grains. But the other standard Zolotnik, which is at the bank (for there are two, used as standards) weighs 69 grains 11 1/25. or 2.divt: 21. gr. 4/100. By the first of these Standards the Russian pound would be equal to 6288 grains Troy— By the second it would be 6627.84. making the difference in one pound of 339.84 grains, or between 5 and 6 per Cent.— It is therefore very natural that there should be so much difference, in the reports of different authorities, and so much uncertainty upon the whole subject since there are two standards, thus widely different from each other, to which equal recurrence is had— Mr: Hynam promised to give me the exact proportions between the Russian and English pounds, as soon as he should ascertain them; and in the mean time lent me some small English Troy-weights with which I can compare mine. He is also very curious on the subject of magnetism, and has an instrument to shew the dip of the needle in different latitudes— He told me he was acquainted with Mr: Churchman, who had given him one of his books.— In the Evening I went with the Ladies and Mr: Gray to the great Theatre, where we saw Gulistan, with d’Alayrac’s music, and la Menteuse per delicatesse, a foolish Comedy in one act.

12. Visit this morning from Mr: Six’s Secretary Mr: Van Zuylen van Nyvelt, with Count Luxbourg, who is going to see Monsieur and Madame de Bray in Livonia— The Chevalier de Bray has obtained the permission to travel which he solicited, and will probably never return to St: Petersburg— Mr: Raimbert, Mr: Montréal, and their nephews the Consolat’s, Mr: Fisher and Mr: Plummer dined with us— I invited several other American Gentlemen, but they were engaged.— I walked in the Summer-garden in the Evening; but found myself with a severe cold all day; and this Evening with a sore breast, and painful cough— In this Climate I have been repeatedly seized, with these remarkable colds and coughs, which have a character peculiar to themselves— This is
already the third time I suffer by them, since the first of May, Old Stile, when I caught one of them at the Catherinenhof ride.— I continue my comparisons of weights, and slowly obtain information concerning them— There is a new Manifesto respecting the Coins, which gives some additional data, for ascertaining the true weight of the Russian pound.— It declares the Rouble of 83 1/3 Zolotniks of pure silver to the pound, and of 5 pounds 6. Zolotniks to the 100 Roubles, to be the Unit of the monies of the Empire— This was already established by an Ukase of Paul I. of 3. October 1797— He had issued a previous Ukase on the same subject— Storch says 24. January 1797.— The manuscript translation of it furnished me by Mr: Montréal, is of 20. January 1797— I have several Roubles both of Paul and Alexander, coined under the last ordinance, and they weigh 321. grains each, Troy weight— Now if 4.86. Zolotniks the weight of the Rouble is = 321. grains Troy, the pound is = 6340.74. grains and the Zolotnik = 66.05— But as an excess or deficiency of 4/96 of a Zolotnik or about 3 grains is allowed on the coinage of each Rouble, and as their general principle is to weigh the blanks, with the allowance of excess in the scale, it is fair to conclude that 1 1/4 grain in each Rouble belongs to this excess, and that the true weight of 4.86. Zolotniks may be settled at 319.4. grains which brings the pound to 6316. as I had fixed it before— The imperfection both of my weights and scales makes it impossible for me to do more than approximate to the truth—

13. Visits this morning, from Mr: Six and Count Rzewuski, and in the Evening from Mr: Fisher and Mr: Ashton— Count Rzewuski told me the subject of his residence here. He was a creditor of the Polish Grand Marechal de la Couronne, Count Oginski; whose Estates were confiscated at the time of Catherine the second’s conquest of the part of Poland in which they were situated— An Ukase of the Empress however declared that those Estates should be answerable for the debts of the former owner, and a part of the lands themselves were allotted to Count Rzewuski for his demand which was of 60,000 ducats— This arrangement was left untouched during the reign of the Emperor Paul—but in 1804. after the Count had been seven years in possession of the lands, an Ukase of the present Emperor, annulled his grant, and a Commission has since been appointed to liquidate his claim— They awarded to him thirty-one thousand ducats, about half the amount of his due, and this award has received the Sanction of the Senate, and of the Emperor— But for the payment even of this he has now been waiting about six months, and will yet have to wait he knows not how long.— Mr: Six says that the news about Count Kotschubey, and Count Severin Potocki’s retirement is certainly not true; but I believe he is not perfectly well informed.— He has written again, and the Ambassador has also written, to urge the French Government to change their policy towards the United States.— I took a short walk this Evening, and pass’d the remainder of the day at home, very unwell with a severe cough.

14. Morning visits from Mr: Harris, and Mr: Barth, supercargo of an American vessel lately arrived at Cronstadt, belonging to Mr: Gerard of Philadelphia— Dined at Count Romanzoff’s, with a company of about twenty-five gentlemen, diplomatic and military— The invitations to the diplomatics was to come en frac; not in full dress, as of course they all were accordingly dressed. I sat at table, between M. de Gourieff the Minister of Finance, and Prince Galitzin, the procureur du Saint Synode; with both of whom I had some conversation.— In the Evening I called upon Mr: Harris, concerning some American Sailors in confinement at Cronstadt, who have written their letters of complaint to me— I afterwards walked on the quay where I met successively Mr: Labensky and Count Lüxbourg.— The latter walked some time with me— He is a severe critic of characters— He told me that Captain Krusenstern had received yesterday the great Cross of the Prussian Order of the red Eagle— By a blunder of the Prussian Court— Captain Krusenstern had sent to the king of Prussia, a copy of the first volume of his voyage, and the king of Prussia concluding that he must be an admiral, sent him this order— But the Statutes of the order required that it should be exclusively reserved for Generals, and Admirals, while Mr: Krusenstern was only Captain of a ship— However, said the Count, the thing is done, and cannot be revoked; but it shews you how these decorations are bestowed; and the truest distinction a man can enjoy, is to wear none of them— The Count himself, has in fact none to wear.

15. Mrs: Adams was very unwell; confined almost the whole day to her bed— My own cough though less severe than yesterday and the day before, was still troublesome— In the Evening I walked in the Summer-Gardens— Remainder of the day at home; the warmth of the weather forbidding exercise in the heat of the day.— I met Count John Potocki on the Quay, who told me that he had been this morning at Court at the Tauridan Palace, where the Grand-Duchess Catherine, and her husband Prince George of Oldenburg now reside— They arrived the day before yesterday by water, from Twer.
Having gone through the volume of Massillon’s Sermons upon the mysteries, I began this day to read that of his funeral eulogies— The first of these which he pronounced was in honour of Henry de Villars, Archbishop of Vienna in Dauphiny— It commenced his reputation as a preacher, and decided his Superiors to fix him in that career, which it seems he entered with reluctance— It is a brilliant piece of composition, but bears strong marks of youth and immature Judgment—overloaded with ornament, especially with those figurative scriptural allusions, which constitute a peculiar character of the author’s manner— The Eulogium includes scarcely any biography— The qualities for which the Archbishop is praised, are generally laudable; but among them is his extraordinary zeal for the persecution of Protestants.— Some instances of what now would be deemed the most illiberal bigotry, are alledged as his most transcendent proofs of merit— His boldness and inflexibility in defending the rights of the Church are also commended, though with some obscurity of expression— There is indeed throughout the discourse a mystical turn of phrase, needing study, to be intelligible. It is in three divisions—considering the Prelate as 1. An upright man 2. A faithful bishop. 3. A charitable and compassionate father— The style is highly oratorical. It concludes with an intimation of doubt whether the Archbishop’s soul was in purgatory, but calling on the Priests to sing the Mass for it— There is also an imitation of the celebrated invocation to Agricola, at the conclusion of his life in Tacitus— This Henry de Villars was an uncle of the famous Marshall Villars, who saved France, or at least Louis 14. by winning the battle of Denain, against Prince Eugene.— I began also this day to read Robinson’s Scripture Characters, and read that of Adam— The author professes to have written them for a plain, Country Congregation; for which they appear to be suitable.

16. Visits this morning from Mr: Harris and Mr: Hurd who is returned from Moscow, and now intends soon to go to England. I dined at Monsieur de Laval’s, at his Country Seat, with a company of about twenty persons— He has a similar company every Monday at dinner, during the Summer; to which both he and Madame de Laval according to the custom of the Country gave me a general invitation— Mrs: Adams did not go with me; being confined to her bed, and this Evening very unwell— Of the company at M. de Laval’s, were the Chevalier d’Italinsky a Connoisseur in Paintings lately returned from Italy—Counts St: Julien and Schenk—The Grand-Veneur Demitri Narishkin, two Baron’s Bühler— Princess Kazitsky, Madame de Laval’s mother and one other Lady— After dinner came some additional company; among whom Princess Woldemar Galitzin, venerable by the length and thickness of her beard— This is no uncommon thing among the ladies of this Sclavonian breed— There is at the Academy of Sciences the portrait of a woman now dead, but with a beard equal to that of Plato— But of living subjects, the Princess Woldemar Galitzin is in this respect of all the females that I have seen, the one who most resembles a Grecian Philosopher— After dinner part of the company walked in the gardens— Went into the hut which M. de Laval calls his hermitage, set down upon the couches round the room, and had some agreeable conversation; in which Madame de Laval, and Count St: Julien principally figured— This Lady appears to me the most amiable, intelligent, and respectable Russian woman that I have seen. Count St: Julien is an old Soldier who has fought many a hard campaign in the Wars, but who has been an Austrian Courtier, all his life— His character is frank, sociable, good-humoured, with a remnant of libertinism, in which he takes a pride, like all the noble rakes of the last century— Licentiousness with regard to women, was peculiarly the fashion of high life in that age— Perhaps it is inseparably the vice of high life in all ages— I partly walked home; not having been out before going to dinner.

17. Mrs: Adams continues ill—confined to her bed, and had this morning a visit from Mrs: Krehmer— From this Evening we may hope she will soon recover— I received visits this morning from Mr: Hurd, from Mr: Boucher, and from Mr: Navarro. I did not go out untill the Evening, and then walked to the foundery.— Having lost my Rest last Night, I found myself almost incapable of application either to writing or reading all this day— This incapacity, from weariness grows upon me with age, and a decline of vigour and activity is already very perceptible to my own self observation— I wrote however as much as I usually accomplish in a day— I read in the Dictionnaire des Arts et Métiers of Jaubert; the principal difficulty of which is in the technical terms, which would require another dictionary for their explanation.

18. Morning visit, early from Mr: Plummer and Captain Lovett— And afterwards from Mr: Harris— Employed the morning in writing— Dined with a small Company at Mr: Six’s. Count St: Julien was there— He had expected the French Ambassador, but he dined with the Emperor— There was a Colonel Donnat there, an Aid de Camp of the king of Holland, who arrived here a few days since— Mr: Six appeared to be depressed in Spirits again, though he took pains to be cheerful and agreeable.— Count Bussche, Mr: Rayneval, and Count Luxbourg were likewise of the Company— I walked in the Evening to the Summer-Gardens.

19. Rain steadily, almost the whole day— In the Evening however, I walked as far as the Foundery— Captain M’Laveen of the ship Rousseau came this morning, and informed me that he should sail in two or three days for Philadelphia— I gave him the packet from Mr: Raimbert to Mr: Gerard, his owner— He is the Captain who some days since was ill treated on board his own ship, and who confined the sailors, who wrote to claim my interference in their favour. I spent the day in writing, and in pursuing the subject of weights measures and coins— Mr: Harris was here this Evening while I was absent.

20. I took the opportunity of a lucid interval in the weather for a half-hour’s walk this morning— From dinner time untill Midnight a heavy and constant rain confined me to the house— Visit from Mr: Six, who informed me that the king of Holland has actually abdicated, and that French troops have taken possession of Amsterdam— The king has transferred his crown to his infant Son, under the Regency of the Queen, and Mr: Six does not yet know whether the Emperor Napoleon will confirm this arrangement, or whether the remaining part of Holland is to be incorporated with France— I enquired of him the cause of this procedure; but he appeared not inclined to talk freely upon the subject, and I did not press it— I conversed with him on the weights, measures and Coins of this Country; and he lent me two publications from which I hoped to gather some additional information— The one is the Manual of the new French weights, measures and Coins; and the other a comparative view of the Russian with all the others known in the world; by Mr: Borel the present private Secretary of Count Romanzoff.— I looked them both over this Evening, and detected some inaccuracies in Mr: Borel’s views of the American Coins— This is the great source of distrust which I have almost universally found upon examination of tables— That I find errors precisely in those with which I am most intimately acquainted, and of the accuracy of which I am a judge— The inference from the error that I ascertain to those which I cannot verify, is so natural, that I have a very qualified confidence in any compilation of tables whatsoever— Mr: Borel’s account, however of the Russian weights and their proportions with those of Paris and England, approach nearer to those on which I had fixed than any others that I have yet met with— Nearer even than the two proportions given by Maudru agree with each other— I received this Evening from Count Romanzoff a Note on the subject, of the outrage committed on the house of Mr: Daschkoff, at his illumination, and entertainment on the anniversary of the Emperor’s accession to the throne— I have also been engaged part of the day, in writing some Notes, on the Manuscript concerning the armed neutrality communicated to me through Mr: Harris; from Count Romanzoff—so that my time is now busily occupied.

21. Continual rain the whole day, so that I did not go out of the house— In the morning I made some extracts, and wrote an Answer to Count Romanzoff’s Note, which I sent— After dinner I examined Mr: Borel’s Tables and Tarbe’s manual of the new french weights and measures a little farther— Mr: Borel in his comparative views of the Russian pound with the English and American Troy Weights gives 91.19 lb. Russian as equal to 100 lb. Troy— This would make the Russian lb. = 6316.482 642/9119 grains Troy—differing from the standard on which I had fixed, only between 13 and 14. 1000th: parts of a grain— He gives 100 lb. Russian as corresponding to 109.66. lb. Troy, which would make the Russian lb = 6316.416 grains Troy, differing 18 one hundredth parts or nearly 1/5 of a grain from my standard, and nearly as much from his own comparison of the Russian weight with the 100 lb. Troy— These differences arise, only from his assuming 100 lb. as the object of comparison and giving only two decimal figures for the fraction— His comparisons with the Avoirdupoise, and with the
french weights present still greater difference of results; arising however in all probability from the same Sources. It is a copious fountain of inaccuracy, that in almost all the tables the smallest weights and measures are compared only to two or three decimal fractions, and then the remnant is left unstated or an excess given without noting its amount— For as the greatest weights and measures are only multiples of the smallest the misstatement of the millionth part of a grain or of an inch becomes an enormous error in the computation of a Million Tuns, or of the distance of a fixed star— I read this Evening to the Ladies three Acts of Regnard’s Légataire Universel.

22. Another rainy and cold day. I found only about an hour before dinner for a walk— The rest of the day I spent at home— Read Massillon’s funeral Eulogy upon Messire Camille de Villeroy Archbishop and Count of Lyons— It is not equal to that of Villars, and indeed appears to me inferior to the general style of the author— He considers the subject of his Discourse as Statesman, and Churchman—as Governor of Lyons and then as Archbishop— He does not panegyrize his Persecution of Protestants; and his topics are all unexceptionable— But the composition is not so well polished, and there are more ludicrous phrases than usual— There are also many repetitions of ideas, contained in the Eulogy of Villars; particularly the imitation of Tacitus, and the closing allusion to purgatory.— In the Evening I read Robinson’s Characters of Cain and Abel.

23. Visits from Mr: Coffin, Mr: Montréal and Mr: Harris this forenoon— Mr: Coffin came to inform me that he intends to sail for Boston to-morrow— Mr: Montreal brought me a Memoir of Messieurs Severin, presented to the Government here, urging the prohibition of importation of refined sugars. Mr: Harris asked for the return of the manuscript upon the armed neutrality; for which I am not yet prepared— I dined with Count Bussche at his house in the Country. It is just out of the Peterhoff gate. The Company consisted of about twelve persons—Mr: Six—Count Schenk—Mr: Navarro—Barons d’Arnim and Mulinen, Mr: Rumigny, &c— In the Evening, I took an hour’s walk, in returning home.

24. I was employed from six this morning, untill three in the afternoon in writing, excepting about half an hour at breakfast, and a visit of about an hour from Count St: Julien, with whom I had much conversation upon the political incidents of the time— He supposes the murder of Count Fersen at Stockholm to have been instigated by a remnant of the Jacobins. Mr: Harris dined with us— In the Evening I resumed the calculations to ascertain the proportions between French and English measures— I sent to Cronstadt some letters for America.

25. I had no interruption of visitors this day; but in pursuit of the proportions between the antient French Pied de Roi, and the English Foot I became absorbed in arithmetical calculations and wasted almost the whole morning— It is a circumstance which I ought to notice and to controul in my own disposition— Any occupation to which a spur of inclination impels me operates as a sort of compulsion upon me, and leaves me no longer master of my own time. The hour for dinner arrived, and I had done nothing of that which was my most urgent business— I dined with Baron Blome the Danish Minister, at his Country Seat. The company was small—Chevalier Brancia,—Lajard—Two sons of M: de Gourieff—M. de Krabbe the Danish Secretary of legation—Baron Hübsch—Count Pouschkin, and two or three other Officers whom I did not know— The French Ambassador who dined with the Emperor, came in the afternoon— I walked in the Summer-Gardens, on the Quay, and home. The Chevalier Brancia told me that the Ministry of Commerce had been assigned to the Department of the Finances in the Counsel, which takes it effectually from the hands of Count Romanzoff—at which he said the Count was not well pleased.

26. I returned this morning the visits of Count Rzewuski and Mr: Navarro, who both reside in the other part of the house where we live— The house forms the corner of the Hobou Nepeudok? or New Street and of the Moika Canal— There are two gates of entrance— One on the Canal and the other on the Street— Ours is that of the Street— I had an hour’s conversation with Count Rzewuski, and sat as long with Mr: Navarro— The Count shewed me two original miniature pictures in enamel; taken from the life by Petitot; of John Sobieski, king of Poland, and his wife, Marie de la Grange d’Arquien: they are executed with the utmost perfection— The Count assured me that I was mistaken in supposing that the present king of Saxony was lineally descended from John Sobieski,—by the female line— Mr: Navarro gave me an account of the proceedings
of the French in Portugal— He holds them in great abhorrence; which is the feeling of all Europe, and almost all America towards them.— The remainder of the morning I employed in writing— Dined with the French Ambassador at his house of Kaminoi ostroff— The company were about sixteen— The Ambassador is a man of the most polished and at the same time most unaffected manners that I ever knew— He lives at the annual expence of a million of Roubles— Has a family of sixty-five persons and keeps fifty-six horses in his stables— He maintains the State and Splendour of an Ambassador with sufficient dignity, but in his manners is modest and unassuming— There is a becoming gravity in his manners, and something in his countenance and eye which indicates hardness as well as polish— The Company as usual was diplomatic— Mr: Six renewed to me in conversation the assurance that the king of Saxony is not a descendant from John Sobieski, and said that he had been reading Coxe’s account of the family this morning— Coxe’s book was the very place where I had found it, and on returning home, I looked at Coxe’s genealogical table of the Sobieski’s, and found that I had not been mistaken— The Ambassador read to us some private letters from his friends at Paris, containing accounts of the disaster at Prince Schwarzenberg the Austrian Ambassador’s Fête given to the Emperor, and Empress of France on occasion of the marriage.— The dancing hall caught fire, and several persons were dangerously burnt—the Ambassador’s brother’s wife perished in the flames—the Russian Consul’s wife, Madam Labensky died the next day— Prince Kurakin the Russian Ambassador, barely escaped with his life; and many others were severely hurt. After returning home, I took a walk to the Summer-Gardens— This day is the thirteenth anniversary of my marriage.

27. I took a short walk this morning; but was prevented from going out in the Evening by Rain— Mr: Harris passed the Evening with us. I continued employed in writing observations upon the manuscript relative to the armed neutrality— This work is composed under the direction of Count Romanzoff—by Mr: Borel and Mr: Gervais; it has been submitted by the Count’s orders to my perusal, with the request that I would make such observations upon it as might occur to me— It is to be published in the course of the present year at Paris— In the Evening, I allowed a couple of hours again to the research concerning weights, measures and Coins.

28. Devoted the morning to the manuscript on the armed neutrality.— I went to Mr: Etter’s shop, and examined his Dictionnaire Universel de Commerce, published at Paris in 1805. respecting weights, measures and coins— I found some information in it; but the same inattention to small fractions, and some of the same inaccuracies, which are in all the tables that I have hitherto consulted. I also weighed with Mr: Hynam’s Troy weights Etter’s Karat weights, used for weighing diamonds and other precious stones—and I found the result agreed within 1/220 of a grain, with the weight as given in Tarbe’s manual, from Paucton— This difference no doubt arises from my having had no weights small enough to mark so minute a fraction— In the Evening I walked to the Summer Gardens— Mr: Smith dined abroad— The weather begins again to be comfortably warm.

29. I continued writing remarks on the manuscript, and brought them to a conclusion— At home untill the Evening, and then walked to the Summer Gardens, and in them— I read Massillon’s funeral Oration upon François Louis de Bourbon, Prince de Conty, who died in 1709— His form of Eulogy is always the same— The Discourse is divided into three parts; which consider the subject 1. As a warrior— 2. As an accomplished personage in civil life— 3. As a man of superior Understanding—Hero—Sage—and Genius— This Prince was really a distinguished character, and in 1697 was elected king of Poland; but before he arrived there found himself supplanted by Augustus 2. whom the pious Bishop of Clermont calls a Jeroboam— There are some national reflections upon the rudesse Germanique; and he says that they are brave as well as the French; but that humanity is peculiar to Frenchmen— Among the topics of praise is one, for his having insisted upon his right of precedence, on some occasion, and not suffering it to be contested— A bad topic for Christian Humility, but a good one for a Courtier— There are as in most of this Orators discourses many keen & bitter reflections upon the great— General Satire, upon Princes, Grandees, rich men, and women, are modes of flattery to individuals of the same Class, and therefore not becoming in a Christian Orator— There are some military details, which are not oratorical, and one ludicrous expression where he says that the Prince at the battle of Nenhausel, was “tout couvert de poussière et de gloire.”— I read also the character of Enoch in Robinson.

30. I received this morning from Archangel a duplicate of a letter from Mr: William Gray, of Boston, dated 16. May and advising me of a vessel, he was sending to Königsberg in Prussia— He requests me to procure a recommendation to a good house there to assist his Captain in transacting the business— I immediately went to Mr: Raimbert’s, and asked their recommendation— They named the House of Schwinck and Koch, to whom I wrote, and at the same time enclosed to them a letter for Captain Groves— Mr: Harris sent to me for the manuscript on the armed neutrality, which I accordingly returned to him— My observations will be sent when a copy of them is made out— Mr: Harris himself was here this afternoon; and spoke of the difficulties which the American vessels arriving at Archangel experience, to obtain admission— And also of Mr: Jewett’s wish to enter into the naval service of this Country.— The Ladies went to the Theatre, and I walked to the foundery.

31. Mr: Roberts and Mr: Harris called on me this morning. Mr: Roberts is to sail in a few days for Baltimore— I gave Mr: Harris the Copy of my remarks upon the manuscript— I paid a visit to Mr: Six— He informed me of the Fate of his Country— The Emperor Napoleon, by a decree of the 10th: of July has annexed the whole Country to France— Amsterdam is to be the third City of the Empire— (Rome was lately declared the second)— The Duke of Parma is to be Governor General— Holland is to send 25 members to the French Legislature—6. Senators—6. Counsellors of State &c— Mr: Six’s functions will cease of course as Minister of Holland; and he expects to go very soon— I shall regret his departure, as I have been on terms of more intimacy with him, than with any other of the Ministers here, and I have found much pleasure and useful instruction in his conversation— This Evening I went to the public Baths, and took a warm Bath— Not however according to the Russian-fashion— A little music by the Ladies after I came home.

Day. Its regular course continues precisely the same as the last Month, and probably will continue for some time; unless affected by the change of the Seasons— As the nights lengthen, the time which I can employ in my Cabinet in writing or reading is diminished— My eyes will not submit to much close-application by artificial light— In the winter I expect again to have much compulsive idleness— I have now no part of the day, on which I can count as my own, excepting the morning before breakfast, and my rising hour continues to vary between 5 and 10. O’Clock— Scarcely any two days in succession alike— I find myself too often hurried; but I never felt less the weariness of occasional hours when Times hangs heavily upon the Spirits— I have many anxious, but scarcely any languid moments— The principal self-dissatisfaction that I now experience is the reflection upon the sort of occupation in which I indulge myself— My Correspondence with America, is not sufficiently frequent— I have totally neglected the study of the Russian language, upon which I had commenced, and feel a strong aversion at resuming it— I waste many hours in obtaining a minute accuracy in the proportions of Russian, English, and French weights measures and Coins, which I shall never attain, and the usefulness of which if I could attain it, is at least problematical— Trahit sua quemque voluptas— My Studies generally command me, and I seldom controul them—
